Publications

Publications are here sorted by multiple criterion (most recent, best of, by themes, by taxonomic groups). Just hover on top of a publication to reveal its details. Only publications created while being part of the Data Zoo Gang are listed here. For the full list of publications of a given team member, please use instead:

  • Google Scholar: Alexandre Courtiol, Liam D. Bailey, Ian J. Rickard.

  • ORCID: Alexandre Courtiol, Liam D. Bailey, Colin Vullioud, Ian J. Rickard, Camille Martinez-Almoyna.

5 most recent

Our last 5 publications are:

  • Dayaram et al. (2021)
  • Tonnabel et al. (2021)
  • Kruszynski et al. (2021)

best of

Here is a short selection of publications we are particularly proud of and which best reflect our involvement and mindset.

  • Radchuk et al. (2019) is a meta-analysis quantifying precisely the extent to which animals (mostly birds) are adapting to changing climate.
  • Vullioud et al. (2019) is an in-depth study of social hierarchy in spotted hyenas revealing how social rank emerges from simple behavioural rules.
  • Corbett et al. (2018) is a review of the causes and consequences of demographic transitions in humans, with an emphasis on human health.
  • Lahdenperä et al. (2018) is a detailed study of how capture influences survival in Asian elephants.
  • Courtiol & Rousset (2017) introduces a new statistical method for modelling the distribution of stable isotopes in the environment.
  • Courtiol, Etienne, et al. (2016) is a minimal model of the evolution of mate choice in both sexes.

by themes

We study wildlife conservation, the ecology and evolution of life history traits, animal behaviour, as well as various aspects of health in wildlife populations. We also design methods that can be applied to study these themes.

Wildlife conservation

Climate change

Radchuk et al. (2019), Mumby et al. (2013a)

Habitat degradation (including urbanisation)

Merling de Chapa et al. (2020), Trinogga et al. (2019), Seltmann et al. (2017)

Reproduction and management

Kretzschmar et al. (2020), Saragusty et al. (2016), Wilting et al. (2015)

Effect of capture and captivity

Lahdenperä et al. (2018), Heinrich et al. (2017), Mumby et al. (2013b)

Life history

Lifespan

Lahdenperä et al. (2018), Corbett et al. (2018), Mumby et al. (2013a), Schneeberger et al. (2014)

Mating, reproductive success and fitness

Tonnabel et al. (2021), Radchuk et al. (2019), Corbett et al. (2018), Courtiol, Tropf, et al. (2016), Pettay et al. (2014), Courtiol et al. (2012)

Effect of climate and seasonality

Radchuk et al. (2019), Mumby et al. (2015), Mumby et al. (2013a), Mumby et al. (2013b), Rickard et al. (2012)

Effect of demography

Corbett et al. (2018), Courtiol et al. (2013)

Behaviour

Perception

Levréro et al. (2015), Cohen et al. (2015), Renoult et al. (2013)

Mate choice

Kretzschmar et al. (2020), Debelle et al. (2017), Courtiol, Etienne, et al. (2016), Santos et al. (2016), Davidian et al. (2016), Etienne et al. (2014)

Migration and dispersion

Kruszynski et al. (2021), Kravchenko et al. (2020), Courtiol et al. (2019), Hobson et al. (2019), Courtiol & Rousset (2017), Davidian et al. (2016)

Social hierarchy

Vullioud et al. (2019)

Health

Diseases

Dayaram et al. (2021), Merling de Chapa et al. (2020), Numberger et al. (2019), Franz et al. (2018), Cui et al. (2016)

Immunity, stress and cicrobiome

Davidian et al. (2015), Alfano et al. (2015), Mumby et al. (2015), Tian et al. (2015), Schneeberger et al. (2014)

MHC

Gillingham et al. (2017), Santos et al. (2016), Gillingham et al. (2016), Sommer et al. (2013)

Methodological contributions

R packages

Fasel et al. (2022), Courtiol et al. (2019), Rousset et al. (2017), Niedballa et al. (2016)

Quantitative methods

Rousset et al. (2017), Courtiol & Rousset (2017), Davidian et al. (2015), Renoult et al. (2013)

Non-invasive methods

Niedballa et al. (2019), Niedballa et al. (2016), Davidian et al. (2015)

Genomics workflow

Paijmans et al. (2016), Sommer et al. (2013)

by taxonomic groups

We mostly work on birds and mammals (including humans) but sometimes venture to study other lifeforms, as well as viruses.

Arthropods

Debelle et al. (2017)

Bats

Kruszynski et al. (2021), Kravchenko et al. (2020), Courtiol et al. (2019), Seltmann et al. (2017), Santos et al. (2016), Schneeberger et al. (2014)

Birds

Merling de Chapa et al. (2020), Radchuk et al. (2019), Gillingham et al. (2017), Gillingham et al. (2016), Renoult et al. (2013)

Carnivores

Vullioud et al. (2019), Heinrich et al. (2017), Davidian et al. (2016), Paijmans et al. (2016), Wilting et al. (2015), Davidian et al. (2015)

Elephants

Lahdenperä et al. (2018), Saragusty et al. (2016), Mumby et al. (2015), Mumby et al. (2013a), Mumby et al. (2013b)

Marsupials

Cui et al. (2016), Alfano et al. (2015)

Plants

Tonnabel et al. (2021)

Primates

Corbett et al. (2018), Courtiol, Tropf, et al. (2016), Levréro et al. (2015), Cohen et al. (2015), Pettay et al. (2014), Courtiol et al. (2013), Courtiol et al. (2012), Rickard et al. (2012)

Rodents

Ungulates
